One of my dreams for Vinous has long been that we would be an incubator for talent, a place where we could discover, nurture and develop the next generation of wine writers. With that in mind, a few years ago we launched the Vinous Young Wine Writer Fellowship, which is intended to give aspiring young wine writers an opportunity to travel and pursue their aspirations.

This year we received a great many high-quality applications. Making a final decision was very difficult. We are thrilled to announce that Laura Bruno is the recipient of the 2022 Vinous Young Wine Writer Fellowship, presented by Capital One. We especially admire Laura's passion for continued wine education and documentation with the desire to share this knowledge through the art of storytelling. I would like to thank everyone who took the time to apply for the 2022 Vinous Young Wine Writer Fellowship.

Today, we raise a glass to congratulate Laura. We can’t wait to share her writing with you! 👏👏👏🎉🥂
What a fabulous dinner. So great to be back. Yum…😍😍😍
Not my usual tasting chez Roulot. Always a student. What I love most…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Quiet night at the Bistro. My preference. Both wines just gorgeous, the Clerget a bit closed but the Mugneret Gibourg is a total pleasure bomb 😍😍😍

Every visit is different. This one concluded with the 2021 Latricieres Chambertin, a vintage I will review next year. Fitting…Latricieres was the first wine I tasted here from bottle many years ago…🤓🤓😊

I am thrilled to announce that Anne Krebiehl MW has joined Vinous in the role of Editor, responsible for covering the wines of Germany, Austria and Alsace starting with the new releases of 2023. I have been following Anne’s work for a number of years and admire her extraordinary knowledge, writing skills and passion for wine.

Anne, German-born but London-based, is a widely published writer, lecturer and wine judge. Her work has been featured in numerous publications, including The World of Fine Wine, Decanter, Wine Enthusiast and Falstaff International Magazine, where she served as editor-in-chief. Anne completed her WSET Diploma in 2010 and was admitted to the Institute of Masters of Wine in September 2014. She is a highly in-demand lecturer and judge at various events throughout the world. Her first book, The Wines of Germany, was published in Infinite Ideas’ Classic Wine Library and won the Domaine Faiveley International Wine Book of the Year 2020 award at the Louis Roederer International Wine Writers’ Awards.

Over the next few months, David Schildknecht will complete his in-progress articles on Austria and Germany and then transition to writing long-form feature articles on a variety of topics where his expertise is unparalleled. Anne will begin 2023 in Alsace and then take over the primary responsibility for reviewing new releases from Germany and Austria.

I have long held a deep interest in the regions, growers and wines of Germany, Austria and Alsace. It has been our ambition to offer subscribers best-in-class coverage of these exciting and dynamic regions. With Anne and David, I believe we have the dream team to do just that.

Please join me in welcoming Anne to Vinous. I am sure you are going to enjoy her insights into the wines of Germany, Austria and Alsace. 🥂🎉🥂🤓🤓🤓
It’s that time of year…2020 Bordeaux…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Soldera 1977-2017…epic tasting set for May 2023 over 2 days, 40+ wines, in NYC, details coming next week. Once in a lifetime for sure…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Something a little different. My favorite spirits of the year, on the homepage now…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Delish…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Time to start cooking. A little inspiration first though. This is the 2016. Still very young. Will be great in an hour or two…😍😍😍

In the mood for Napa Cabernet Sauvignon tonight. Wow, is this great. So fresh and a vibrant. Much more like the barrel sample than it was from bottle in the early going. I love the energy and purity here. Superb. 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

What an absolute delight! 2011 is not a vintage I have tasted much recently. The Tre Tine is gorgeous, bright and lively, with terrific energy and fine balance. Just approaching it’s first plateau of maturity. No rush to drink this. 

Hope everyone is enjoying this holiday weekend. Very ❄️❄️❄️ in New York, and that means it’s Barolo time…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓🎉🎄❄️
Magnificent. Drinking not tasting…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Just superb. Love this vintage, and what’s not to love? Drinking, not tasting…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Best kitchen sink ever…🤪🤪🤪. Many thanks to our gracious hosts. Drinking, not tasting 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Festa del Barolo is fast approaching. We have a bunch of new events next year, starting with the first in a series of village focused dinners. First up is a dinner focusing on Verduno, with a superb collection of wines from Fratelli Alessandria, Burlotto and Castello di Verduno, February 1 at Locanda Verde in NYC. We are down to our last remaining spots. Info is on the Events section of the Vinous website. It’s going to be great. 

I love this wine. The Acclivi to me is like the Clos St. Jacques at Rousseau, if you know what I mean. Sublime and more accessible than the very big guns, not as expensive, and in the best vintages truly superb. Andiamo!!! 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Raveneau and Simple Minds. We are good. Very good. Fabulous bottle of the 2015, which is just starting to soften. Loved it. Drinking, not tasting…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Classics never go out of style…😍😍😍😋😋😋

What a year it has been. We started with a gradual return to a more normal world as the grip of Covid softened and finished tremendously busy. 

Two thousand twenty two was our best year ever at Vinous. I would like to thank our readers around the world for making that possible, and our entire team for a huge effort. Next year is our tenth anniversary…we are setting our sights even higher! These are some of the many memorable events of 2022:

1) the inaugural edition of Napa in the City
2) tasting the DRC 2019s
3) La Festa del Barolo
4) Complete vertical of Vinedo Chadwick
5) Fabulous dinner at TentaziOni, Bordeaux
6) Ridge 60th anniversary tasting 
7) Vinous Bruno Giacosa dinner
8) Vinous Selosse dinner
9) Unforgettable dinner at Il Centro, Priocca
10) New Vinous Maps for 2022: SLH and Sonoma Valley Collection 

Hope everyone has a great New Year’s🥂🥂🥂
First day of the year. Great to be in the office early. Time to set some goals and commit them to paper. We will see what things look like in 12 months’ time. Hopefully I do OK 😊.
Alessandro Masnaghetti and I are cooking up something special for those who are coming to the Verduno dinner. It’s going to be…superb…I think 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Absolutely delicious. So great to drink this with mom, dad & family 😍😍😍

Very sad to wake up today with the news of Luciano Sandrone’s passing. He was a titan, a grower who changed the history of Barolo and opened the door for so many younger producers who have followed. Whereas many of the winemakers of his generation were brash and flamboyant, Sandrone was soft spoken and introspective. I will remember him for his kindness and graciousness, qualities that are all too rare in today’s world. 

Luciano Sandrone is pictured here with his wife, Mariuccia, brother Luca and daughter Barbara. Although Luciano’s is the name on the label, it has always been a family affair here. My hope is that it remains so for many, many years to come.

All of us at Vinous extend our deepest condolences to the Sandrone family…🙏🙏🙏

Still thinking about Luciano Sandrone’s passing a few days ago. Over the years I have been fortunate to have many remarkable tastings at the estate. This one, in 2017, was one of the best. Tasted virtually every wine ever made here. Just the Sandrone family, Alessandro Masnaghetti and yours truly. Unforgettable…🙏
January means Sonoma, as it has for many years now. Always great to taste wines of place, great to always be a student…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Small tasting of 38 2021s finishes with 2 wines I first tasted from tank during harvest. My work is done…for now…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Carlisle 2021s to wrap up the day…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Vinous Maps…a sampling of our production….Sonoma Valley, by nested AVA, Napa Valley by AVA, Santa Lucía Highlands AVA and West Sonoma Coast AVA, plus a whole stack of single ranch maps on the left, Platt and Occidental on top…Always a student 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Festa del Barolo LA is coming up on Saturday Jan. 28 at Marino Ristorante. There’s going to be a ton of great wine there. We are down to the last seats…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Very few people are true originals. Jeff Beck was exactly that. One of a kind. A major influence for me starting in my teenage years. Saw him live twice on the tour he co-headlined with Stevie Ray Vaughan. He was unreal. Unlike many of his contemporaries, Beck continued to evolve as a musician for decades after that…what a loss. RIP 🙏💔
A very nice end to the week…until tomorrow am 😊😊😊🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍The 2012 is still an infant…
Sun looks like it might make an appearance after days of torrential rain. Map research today….Coombsville is nearing completion. This is Paul Hobbs’ Nathan Coombs Estate…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

It may have been overcast and rainy yesterday, but it was a brilliant day just the same. A real privilege to spend the morning with two Napa Valley icons. I will admit, showing Warren Winiarksi all our map work was a huge thrill and honor that I will never forget. And his Italian is pretty great too…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍. The pics:

1) Warren Winiarksi and John Kongsgaard at Winiarski’s Arcadia ranch in Coombsville, in front of the blocks Kongsgaard gets for their Napa Valley Chardonnay
2) The original remaining Chardonnay at Kongsgaard’s Stonecrest vineyard (aka The Judge) planted in 1975
3) Furthering my education in Coombsville. Being a student is the best…

Festa del Barolo Los Angeles is coming up next weekend, Saturday January 28 at Marino Restaurant. Check out the wines for the gala dinner, all magnums 😱😱😱. Naturally 😊. We are down to our last few seats for Festa LA-style. It’s going to be great. See you there…! @silviaaltare79 @la_spinetta @oddero @paoloscavino @sandroneluciano @__chiara_boschis__xx @pierobenevelli @francescorinaldiefigli @giacomofenocchio @vietti_vino
What can I say? Patience has never been my greatest virtue 😂😂😂Yum…😍😍😍

The global supply of Barolo took a major hit last night at La Festa del Barolo Los Angeles. The Vinous LA contingent brought the 🔥🔥🔥. New York is going to have to be on their game next weekend 😊😊😊. Many thanks to everyone who made this happen. The growers shared truly special wines, all magnums at dinner last night. Sal, Mario and the team at Marino outdid themselves. Wow. Our team of sommeliers headed by Alex Weil dealt admirably with the craziness. Last but certainly not least, our team led by Marzia, James, Gabriella, Brenna and Ellen put in a ton of work to make sure every detail was perfect. New York is next, but we will be back. Thank you LA! ☀️♥️🎉🍷
New York City in all its splendor as we get ready to kick off La Festa del Barolo…60 minutes to game time…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

The room is set. Getting ready to kick off the first in our series of single-village dinners at Festa del Barolo. Tonight the focus is on Verduno. Special thanks to our sponsors Capital One and Asprey London, and of course everyone who has set aside their time to be with us! @festadelbarolonyc 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Festa del Barolo NYC kicked off last night with the first in a series of single-village dinners at Festa designed to focus on the specific characteristics of the main Barolo villages. Education + fun 😊. Last night the focus was on Verduno, with a stunning collection of wines from Castello di Verduno, Fratelli Alessandria and Burlotto, presented by Mario Andrion, Vittore Alessandria and Fabio Alessandria. Many thanks to Andrew Carmellini, Josh Nadel and the entire team at Locanda Verde for such a special dinner, and of course to our many guests who shared their evening with us…🔥🔥🔥🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍. Next… @lafestadelbarolonyc @fratellialessandria @castello_di_verduno #burlotto

The Vineyards of Verduno Map. This is a special edition map we created for last night’s Verduno dinner at La Festa del Barolo. It’s a fold out 4 page map that shows Verduno, with the vineyards of Castello di Verduno, Fratelli Alessandria and Burlotto highlighted. The image is from Alessandro Masnaghetti’s forthcoming book Barolo MGA Third Edition, scheduled for release in October 2023. Text on each estate and Verduno is by yours truly, design is by our own Brenna Ritchey. Thank you to our team for taking an idea and turning into something real…🤓🤓🤓🔥🔥🔥 @festadelbarolonyc @fratellialessandria @castello_di_verduno #burlotto
Are we really going to open all of these? Apparently so. Cantina/Bartolo Mascarello back to 1955…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍 @festadelbarolonyc
Quality control. Tough job, but someone’s gotta do it…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍. Very happy to have more 1958 and 1955, but for some of these vintages this is it for me… @festadelbarolonyc

Bartolo Mascarello was the first grower I met in Piedmont, so the wines have always had special significance. His 1982 was an early reference point (it’s still great 😊). It was such a thrill to his this dinner last night at Legacy Records. Best meal I have ever had there. The kitchen team led by Dave Metz turned out a brilliant menu. The bar is set high for next time! Sommeliers Celia Erickson and Theo Lieberman handled the wines (and all of my quirks) with expert care. It’s important to me when we do dinners like this that guests taste the benchmarks, so the vintages were the best of the best: 2016, 2013, 2010, 2008, 2006, 2005, 2004, 2001, 1999, 1996, 1990, 1989, 1988, 1985, 1982, 1978, 1964, 1958 & 1955. Impossible to pick favorites, but some wines were especially great, including the 2010, 2008, 1989, 1982 and 1964, but overall these were all exceptionally good examples of their respective vintages. As always, we strive to deliver education + pleasure 😊. Busy day today as @lafestadelbarolonyc continues…🔥🔥🔥🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

We have long wanted to expand Festa del Barolo to the other great Nebbiolo producing regions. Can’t say we have totally figured it out yet, but we are delighted to host Aldo Vacca of Produttori del Barbaresco today for lunch and a complete horizontal of the 2017 Riservas plus the new multi-vineyard 2016 Riserva. We are thrilled to be at Danny Meyer’s Union Square Cafe, still a NYC icon after all these years…😊😊😊😍😍😍
Festa del Barolo getting started. What can I say, some of the tables are looking insane…Greatest Barolo Show on Earth…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Always great to get an invite to the Festa del Barolo preparty. Game on…😊😊😊😍😍😍

Festa del Barolo Big Bottle BYOB Gala Dinner & Charity Auction was a stunning success last night. Such a great vibe in the room. Thank you to everyone who helped make last night truly unforgettable. First two pics are some of the wines at my table, Pic 3 is what the Rinaldi table enjoyed 🔥🔥🔥. Food was terrific. Our team of sommeliers led by Jenni Guizio and Josh Nadel did a tremendous job… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

A very emotional end to this year’s Festa del Barolo, with the recent passing of Annalisa Rinaldi and Luciano Sandrone plus Luca and Elena Currado Vietti’s last event representing the Vietti winery. A well deserved standing ovation for the Currado Viettis to finish out the 2018 Barolo masterclass. Not a dry eye in the house. Few families have done more to promote Barolo abroad, especially in the US. No one who was there will ever forget it. I certainly won’t…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓🍷🍷🍷@lafestadelbarolonyc

Coming Soon…Napa in the City 2023. Your chance to meet a group of Napa Valley’s most iconic winemakers and a number of rising stars. Oh yeah…and taste a ton of amazing wines, too. Our events strive to deliver unparalleled educational experiences. If you want to taste the best Napa Valley has to offer and learn about the great Napa terroirs, this is the place to be. There is nothing like Napa in the City. Anywhere in the world. 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍. Details on the Vinous homepage. #philiptogni #kongsgaard #napa #napavalley #cabernetsauvignon

The Vinous Collection of Napa Valley Maps. Last year we gave this book out as a gift to everyone who attended the Napa in the City masterclass tasting. We are hard at work on this year’s book. For now, let me just say we have upped our game big time…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Napa Valley 2020 & 2021 reviews are out now on our home page. It’s one of the most extensive articles I have ever written on Napa Valley, and certainly the most complex to put together because of all the nuances of these two vintages 🤓🤓🤓. This is Forman on a glorious late fall day…in 2022 😊.

Mike Stern…one of my biggest influences. He blew the roof off the place the other night at Birdland with Frank Vignola and his group. Sounds as good as ever, and I started going to his shows when I was in my teens. Inspiring…👏👏👏🤓🤓🤓

Here’s another cool map from our forthcoming book for the 2023 Napa in the City 2019 Masterclass tasting. It shows Ulysses and the other important vineyards in the neighborhood, including Missouri Hopper, MBar Ranch, Vine Hill Ranch and others. Among other things, this map gives a good idea of the southern portion of the Oakville bench and how that terrain melds into the hillsides…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
La Boloree and Coltrane. Perfect for a relaxing Sunday night. Similar themes of deconstruction and reinvention…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Great to be at the Garden last night. Rangers dominated for long stretches, but could not score. Jets made the best of their chances. This was a rare highlight. Fun night just the same 😊😊😊
A nice touch to kick off a fabulous dinner at Ci Siamo, which is fast becoming one of my favorite places in NYC. Full report coming soon…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Bordeaux 2020 is out. It is my favorite vintage of the 2018-2019-2020 ‘trilogy.’ These are some of the great Saint-Emilions of 2020. I tasted  800+ wines for this report, my fourth big article of the year so far. I am taking the weekend OFF 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A fine day at Vinous. Today we look at a handful of new releases from Tuscany and the 2019 Bordeaux from the recent Southwold tasting in a superb report from Neal. Plenty to check out…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Unabashedly opulent and flamboyant. A great example of this vintage and site 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Two seats just opened for our Togni vertical this Thursday. Stunning collection of wines back to 1983. Events@vinous.com if you have an interest. It’s going to be epic 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Coombsville map is almost done. Super proud of this one, our 8th Napa Valley map and 16th map so far. The Sandlands 2017 Merlot has been an inspiration over these last few days. It was made from the Michael Black Vineyard, planted in the mid 1980s by Michael Black, who ran vineyard operations for Simi and also played a role in the development of a number of sites including Peter Michael and Flowers. As much as I love tasting and reviewing wines, I think our maps may ultimatimately be a longer lasting contribution to California wine culture in the US and abroad…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
DRC 2020s, the complete range. Always an instructive and educational tasting…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Great dinner with my core NYC group last night at Torrisi. We have shared many amazing memories over the years. To me, that’s what wine is ultimately all about. People and memories. All of these wines were gorgeous but I adored the 2010 Coche Charlemagne and DRC Montrachet…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Epic Togni dinner last night with Lisa Togni back to the inaugural 1983, of which only 90 cases were made. I also loved the 1991. Sometimes great wines are the result of unusual circumstances. In 1991, the tanks were full of fermenting Sauvignon Blanc, so the Cabernet was left to hang a bit longer than anticipated. The result is a wine that is still opulent, exotic and stunning in its beauty. Magnificent. Also loved the 1983, 1994, 2001, 2010 and 2013 among others. Many thanks to the team at Union Square Cafe for a delicious dinner and top notch service. Always such a pleasure to do events there. 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
The room is set for the greatest Napa Valley dinner on earth…can’t wait…🤓🤓🤓😊😍😍😍
Epic dinner last night at Napa in City, benchmark wines all over the place… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A small tasting at Taittinger 😊. So great to be back in Champagne… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Vins clairs at Roederer. Always one of my favorite tastings of the year, as it is a great opportunity to really focus on details and nuances…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A mini-vertical of Bollinger VVF. Doesn’t happen every day. Especially loved the 2008 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Loved this on release….in great shape today….🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Fun night out with friends. Good wines, but an even better time 😉
A fine visit at Billecart…most improved house in Champagne over the last few years, IMO, especially with regards to the NV Champagnes 🤓🤓🤓

Fabulous dinner at Terre de Craie, and sensational wines to match. Rousseau 2001 Beze - just tremendous fruit purity; Lafon 2014 Perrieres - electric tension. Energizing wines, and a great night out… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

I like tasting wine, but I like being in vineyards more 😊. This is one of the Coulon family’s parcels, Chardonnay on clay in Coulommes La Montagne, used for their L'Hommée Champagne. The cover crop is all natural, but if you look close you will see little bits of blue plastic found throughout vineyards in Champagne that are a reminder of the 1970s, when trash from nearby homes was used as fertilizer.  It’s very different today…🤓🤓🤓

First time I visited Ulysse Collin was in 2011. Time flies. Back then the wines were potent but also a bit rustic at times. That is rarely the case these days. Olivier Collin and Sandra Zaragoza have done a remarkable job building their domaine since its inception just 20 years ago. This vertical of the Rose de Saignee Les Maillons, one of my favorites here, was incredibly educational. And the wines were pretty great too… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Roses de Jeanne…very cool retrospective. I still remember the first time I tasted Cédric Bouchard’s Champagnes. They made a deep impression then, and still do today…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Had a fabulous stay at L’Asiette Champenoise this week. The only problem was that it was not long enough 😊. Dinner was sublime, maybe the best ever. I still remember the first time I stayed here, about 15 years ago. The restaurant was OK and the hotel was, well it was just dreary. Since then the Lallement family, led by Arnaud Lallement, have continued to invest and improve quality, taking L’Assiette to the stars, and in turn helping elevate the image of Champagne as a region. That is both remarkable and inspiring. Bravo! Can’t wait to go back…😋😋😋😍😍😍

One of my favorite wines from a region I don’t personally cover. So great to back at Les Avises. It’s a place that attracts wine people from all over the world. You never know who you will run into. A must in my book…😋😋😋😍😍😍

Back in NYC, back at The Pool 😊. Wonderful birthday party last night, with some very special wines, most of them from magnum. A real privilege to drink these. The 1985 Dom Perignon Rose was haunting for its aromatics and balance, while the 2002 Cristal impressed with its creaminess and resonance. I have to admit, I am not a huge Ramonet fan (go ahead and shoot me) but the 2014 Bienvenues was positively stellar. Soldera 2004 also great. The 1971 Petrus is a wine of its era. Sadly the 1982 Latour was corked. Probably my favorite wine of the night was the 1999 Dujac Bonnes Mares. Superb, and also incredibly young. Some of their wines might be more famous, but for me, when I can choose, my favorite Dujac grand cru is Bonnes Mares. The only problem is it takes forever to come around. Good problems to have. A wonderful night of wine and friendship…😍😍😍🎉🎂🥂

Time to get ready for the next Vinous event. Soldera 1977 to … Whenever we stop opening bottles. It will be over 2 days, May 12 and 13. Something like 40 different wines. Can’t wait. I fished this bottle out of the cellar today… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

I love this wine. Bought six bottles a few days after I tasted the 2015 Volnays from barrel. Every bottle has been great. The 2015 is still fresh, in fact it was even better after I forgot about it in a decanter overnight 😂. Delish 😍😍😍

Coombsville map is pretty much all wrapped up. It’s a map, plus a history of the appellation and write ups of all the main vineyard sites, with never before seen 3D maps and illustrations of soil types. Tulocay bottled what I think is the first Coombsville vineyard designate (and labeled) wine, their 1975 Pinot Noir from Haynes. Another day in the office 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍 #coombsvilleava #napavalley #napawine

Josh Raynolds In Memoriam (1962-2023)

It is with great sadness and a heavy heart that we share the news of the passing of our esteemed colleague Josh Raynolds.
 
Josh joined Vinous in 2014 from the International Wine Cellar, where he worked with Stephen Tanzer for many years. He was an integral part of our team for nearly a decade. Josh’s knowledge of wine had no limits. Over the years he published articles on wines from a wide range of regions including the Rhône, Beaujolais, Spain, Oregon, California, Australia, Chile and Champagne, as well as his eagerly awaited annual Rosé buyers’ guide.
 
Josh was a frequent speaker at events and conferences, offering straight-shooting insight born of deep experience. Over the years and decades, Josh built long-lasting relationships with winemakers and members of the trade based on mutual respect. His contributions to the world of wine will continue to be enjoyed by many for years to come. More than anything else, we will miss Josh’s inimitable wit, sense of humor and encyclopedic cultural references. We will miss his passion for food and wine, and his ability to remind us that what we spend our time analyzing is meant to be fun.
 
All of us at Vinous extend our deepest condolences to his wife Merrie Louise, daughters Frances and Barbara Ann, and their extended family.
 
The Raynolds family has created a Facebook Group Josh Raynolds Updates, for those of you who wish to pay your respects to Josh and his family. They invite you to upload photos and videos of Josh and share memories. The family will share funeral arrangements and other details on the Facebook page shortly.
 
May the earth be light on you, Josh.
🙏🙏🙏 #joshreynolds

Just a brief note to thank eveyone who has sent us a comment, email, text etc. on the recent passing of Josh Raynolds. Your kind words mean so much to us during this difficult time. The hundreds of messages we have received are a testament to how much Josh was loved, admired and respected. Please keep the Raynolds family in your thoughts and prayers 🙏🙏🙏 #joshraynolds
Heading to Vicenza soon. It’s one of my favorite towns in Italy, but have not been in a while. What’s the latest intel on best places to eat 😋😋😋?

Always an exciting moment. This is our new Coombsville map a few days away from being printed. The top section of this photo is a history of the appellation that I wrote; history, weather, geology, soils, descriptions of key vineyard sites etc. The bottom part is a stunning map from @map_man_masna with striking topographical detail. Thank you to everyone who spent time with us and shared their knowledge, and a huge thank you to our own Brenna Ritchey who worked tirelessly to get us to this point…and hopefully beyond 😊. I am especially proud of this map and can’t wait to share it with you. Maps are…forever 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍.
A look back at 2001 Napa Valley, the first vintage I tasted comprehensively (at age 10) with Bob Parker. On the homepage now. So great to revisit these wines 😊😊😊😍😍😍 #napavalley #napavalleycabernet

I love Veneto. I got to know the region well when I lived in Italy as an expat in the early 2000s, had many clients here. It’s a great region for so many things…art, history, architecture, food, wine, cycling and more. This weekend I am taking the kids on an exploration of Palladian architecture. The Teatro Olympico is stunning. BTW…of course you have to visit the big art cities in Italy,  but I have always loved the smaller cities much more…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Castello di Monsanto Chianti Classico Riserva Il Poggio 1962-2017. The most complete vertical of this wine ever done at the estate. I learned a ton. Another article we published this week 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍 #castellomonsanto #chianticlassico #chiantilovers
Una bionda media…. 😜😉

Very tasty capretto. I don’t have it often, but when I do, I really enjoy it. Wonderful dinner with the kiddos tonight. Delcious food…the sort of cooking that is deceptively simple, and yet is nearly impossible to find outside of Italy…. 😋😋😋😍😍😍
La Rotonda. By now I have lost count of how many times I have been here. Always stunning and inspiring… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

We had an exquisite dinner at Al Fiume. More than anything else, though, I am incredibly grateful for everyone who is working in restaurants and hotels this holiday weekend. Working in the hospitality industry is hard. I have done it. You are putting in long hours, often doing very physical work, while other people are with family, friends, celebrating holidays, special occasions and having fun. Dealing with the public can be brutal. So, a big Thank You! 😋😋😋
Chianti Classico is just breathtaking. Have been coming here for more than 30 years and it never gets old… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
For my latest trick, I have managed to travel into the future…🤓😍🤓😍🤓😍

Monte Rosso. One of the most historically significant vineyards in California. This excerpt from our Moon Mountain District Map compares varietal breakdown in 1975 to the present. The evolution of Moon Mountain is one is the many topics we will cover on June 3, when I host what is going to be an incredible masterclass featuring a number of top winemakers.

It’s an absolutely stellar panel featuring:
 
Jeff Baker (Stone Edge Farm Estate), Erich Bradley (Repris), Mark Herold (Kamen, B Wise), Phil Coturri (Enterprise Vineyards), Danielle Langlois (Lasseter), Mark Williams (Louis M. Martini), Jason Jardine (Hanzell), Morgan Twain-Peterson MW (Bedrock) & Jason Kesner (Kistler Vineyards).

Check out the Vinous home page for more details, including links for purchasing tickets. It’s going to be great 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
 
@stoneedgefarmwinery, @repriswines, @kamenwines, @bwisevineyards, @enterprisevineyards, @lasseterwinery, @louismmartiniwinery, @hanzellfarm, @bedrockwines, @kistlervineyards @moonmountaindistrict

“We have some wines to taste,” says Helene Genin at Latour. Every vintage en primeur starts from ground zero. Taste, talk to winemakers and repeat over and over. It’s an exercise in connecting the dots first. That’s the easy part. Then having the courage and conviction to write what you truly think. That is what wine criticism truly is 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

The Vinous Map of St. Helena & Conn Valley. It’s one of our best selling maps, but it’s also now out of stock so we are preparing the Second Edition. If you are a winemaker, owner or vineyard manager and have had changes to your holdings please send your updates to maps@vinous.com Can’t wait to share the Second Edition with you, as there are a number of important updates…Ecotone, Clos Abeille, Thorevilos and more. Maps are forever 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

“I figure I have another 20-25 years left,“ a very sprightly Bernard Magrez tells me. At 87 years of age, Magrez is sharp as a tack. Bordeaux is of course famous for coveted, high-end wines, but there are a ton of great values to be had too. La Tour Carnet is one of my favorites. And it ages beautifully 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Larcis Ducasse…might be the single most under the radar chateau in Bordeaux…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
I will give a free one year subscription to Vinous to the first person who correctly identifies where this photo was taken from…estate and place within the estate. Who’s up to it????
More Bordeaux trivia? I will make it easier this time. I will give a free one year subscription to Vinous to the first person who answers correctly. Which vineyard is this? 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Can’t wait to moderate this tasting next weekend at Inspire Napa Valley. What an incredible panel…Each of us has chosen a wine that deeply influenced us. I have no idea what the other wines are 😊. I am sure it will be great 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Beach wines with Mom & Dad. A fine weekend… 🐠🐬♥️😍😍😍

Save the Date: Monday June 12 Alessandro Masnaghetti and I will lead two seminars on the great wines of Barbaresco. The morning session is a masterclass tasting of the 2020s while the afternoon session is dedicated to an exploration of terroir in Barbaresco. Space is limited and is by invite only for these seminars done in partnership with Enoteca del Barbaresco. Please check out the link in my bio for the details. Hope to see you there! 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Vino Nobile di Montepulciano is one of Italy’s most historic wines and appellations. It will be interring to see how the appellation develops with the new Pieve district denominations. I will be leading two masterclasses (trade only) next week with wines I have chosen: May 8 in Boston and May 10 in NYC. Contact the event organizer at info@ieemusa.com to sign up. See you there… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
First presentation and tasting for our new Coombsville map. Stanford Graduate School of Business. Should be a fab tasting….🤓🤓🤓😍😍😊
Class is in session. Great to be back at The Stanford Gradual School of Business for this seminar on Coombsville…wine, places and people. Studying can be fun 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

social_posts.post_text: Super fun and educational tasting…Colgin Tychson Hill 2002-2019. Fascinating to observe the evolution of style over time…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Drinking not tasting. Great way to start Inspire Napa Valley. It’s the 2013 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Fabulous event yesterday at CIA Copia to launch our new Coombsville AVA map. It’s our 8th Napa Valley AVA map and 16th overall. The Coombsville Collection is comprised of an AVA map plus individual maps of some of the most notable vineyards in the AVA. My favorite part of the day was listening to Paul Hobbs as he recalled tasting Farella Cabernet from barrel as a young winemaker at Robert Mondavi Winery and the questions that followed from Warren Winiarski. So interesting. A great afternoon all around… 🤓🤓🤓😊😊😊
I really like what I am tasting from Hall these days. I think it’s just the beginning under winemaker Megan Gunderson’s stewardship here… 🤓🤓🤓

Fabulous dinner last night at Inspire Napa Valley to raise funds and awareness for Alzheimer’s research. These are the wines I brought to share with my table and some of our guests. Great to see the active involvement of so many top wineries. Thank you to our benefactors for your generous support. 👏👏👏🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
So great to be back in Boston. Larger than expected turnout for my Vino Nobile masterclass. Lots of tough questions for a Monday morning 😊😊😊😍😍😍

MIT Sloan. Where it all started for me. This is where I founded Piedmont Report. A totally chance encounter with a professor led to an introduction to Robert Parker. A few weeks later I had my interview. I was so nervous I did not sleep the night before. Bob offered me a job on the spot. I had been writing professionally for less than two years. So great to hang with the wine club. Always follow your instincts. No regrets. Ever. 🤓🤓🤓

Another packed room yesterday for my seminar on Vino Nobile. We tasted through a number of wines I picked to show various attributes of style and approach, plus took an early look at the Pieves, the new Nobile UGAs that are expected to be approved shortly. Super fun and hopefully educational too 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Inspire Napa Valley raised over $1m for Alzheimer’s research last weekend. Thank you to all our benefactors for your generous support. In this pic Brad Grimes of Abreu (L) and Jorge Delgado of Screaming Eagle (R) keep a watchful eye to make sure I don’t ruin the salmon. Cooking outdoors at Chappellet during the middle of a rainstorm was quite the adventure, but we made it! 😊😜🤓🙏🎉

Our two-day Soldera tasting starts later, so a little warm up was in order last night. Impossible to pick favorites from this lineup. Great wines and an even better discussion about them. Drinking (not too much), not tasting 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Getting ready for tonight’s epic tasting by revisiting some of my video interviews with Gianfranco Soldera. This clip is from 2019. Precious memories for sure 🤓🤓🤓

Day 2 of our Soldera event was even better than Day 1 by all accounts in the room…

I used to visit Gianfranco Soldera annually when I covered Brunello di Montalcino. Although I no longer cover new releases, I think that distance allowed me to appreciate these wines with a different perspective. Quite simply, I was blown away by what we tasted. For starters, we opened 48 bottles over two days. There were zero corked wines and only one off bottle. There are very few producers in the world, from any region, who can match that level of consistency over five decades. All the wines were pristine. Look at Pic 2 for what color is supposed to be like in these wines - vibrant red and translucent - no browning or cloudiness in any wine back to 1977. Riper wines like 1983 and 1990 Riservas are darker in hue, but still remarkably fresh.

I would like to thank our guests for sharing in this amazing weekend, especially those who traveled from afar (including from Brazil, Switzerland, Italy, Utah and Texas) to join us. Thank you to our team headed by @gabriellalaloma for making everything run smoothly. Thanks also to Gramercy Tavern's Director of Beverage Erin Healy and team for their professionalism, passion, attention to detail and understanding of the moment. I would also like to thank our sponsors Asprey and Glasvin for their support. To Il Professore: sei unico! Without further ado, the wines:

Inspiration for today. Still a great album all these years later. Learning some of these songs in high school was quite the challenge. Saw Rush live once in the mid 1980s. My friends and I snuck into the arena early, heard sound check…I was just blown away by how great they sounded. And they played it all live….🤓🤓🤓
Just published a bunch of new Sonoma reviews: Arista, Desire Lines, Donelan, Drew, Ferren, Fine Disregard, Hanzell, Hirsch, Ridge and Rochioli 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Check out this new Moon Mountain District AVA map with callouts. Killer. This is a custom map we did for a tasting I am moderating on June 3. It shows the entire AVA with callouts for each vineyard/winery in the tasting. One of the many ways our maps can be used for educational tastings and events.

It’s an absolutely stellar panel featuring:
 
Jeff Baker (Stone Edge Farm Estate), Erich Bradley (Repris), Mark Herold (Kamen, B Wise), Phil Coturri (Enterprise Vineyards), Danielle Langlois (Lasseter), Mark Williams (Louis M. Martini), Jason Jardine (Hanzell), Morgan Twain-Peterson MW (Bedrock) & Jason Kesner (Kistler Vineyards).

Ten years ago today we turned on the lights at Vinous. It’s been an incredible ride. We would like to thank our readers all around the world for giving us the opportunity to do what we do.

It's a bittersweet anniversary, to be honest. We are mourning Josh. His presence is still very much felt. At the same time, we are happy to welcome Angus Hughson, Anne Krebiehl MW and Nicolas Greinacher, and see several members of our team take on expanded roles as we continue to grow. On a personal level, am so inspired by the exceptional quality of the work of my colleagues. Being able to do what you love most every day is an immense privilege that is not lost on me. 

Our commitment remains the same as it was ten years ago: to offer the best wine criticism and writing available anywhere. We will continue to work towards that goal. 🎉🎉🎉🥂🥂🥂🎂🎂🎂
Today I finished a Selosse article, finished a Giacosa article, made good progress on a Cristal vertical and tasted some Roses for a report next week. Love this job 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Our new Coombsville Vineyard Map is now available for purchase. It’s the 16th California map we have done in partnership with Alessandro Masnaghetti. Check out the link on my bio or go to the Maps tab on Vinous.com

We have always wanted Vinous to be about more than just reviews and scores. As part of that mission, we make all of our published maps available for viewing for free to subscribers. #mapsareforever 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
New Rose releases today on Vinous. It’s a team effort this year. This is one of my favorites…😋😋😋

It’s been a busy week. We also published a small report on Champagne ahead of my larger article later this year. This is Fred Savart with a few of his wine globes, a new Back to the Future-like version of the glass demijohn. Producers are trialing glass as a potential alternative and/or complement to oak barrels, casks, amphora etc…to me the globes are just like a very big bottle 😂. Savart’s 2019 Le Monts des Chrétiens is one of the most impressive Champagnes I have tasted so far this year…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Started the long weekend off early last night with this gem. At the outset there was not a lot of optimism or enthusiasm for the year, but the best 2014s have turned out to be terrific. I especially admire their verve and tension…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Gorgeous lunch wines on the day we honor all of those who have made the ultimate sacrifice so we can enjoy our essential freedoms. Thank you. 🙏

More nice wines over the weekend. A real privilege to drink these with a small group. The 2002 Comtes de Champagne is always great, but it is a little greater from the big bottle 😊. I also loved the 2019 Rousseau Clos de la Roche. It’s not a wine I taste too often, so I was curious to check it out. Loved the marriage of 2019 Rousseau fruit with the minerality and savoriness of Clos de la Roche. Far too young to deliver maximum pleasure but fascinating to taste today. The 2010 Cerbaiona is massive, but also starting to show the first signs of aromatic development. The 2010 DRC Corton was especially savory and earthy. The whites, they were all delicious but I must admit I find many whites too lean these days 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

📌 Antonio Galloni, protagonista di Espressione Barbaresco 2023

Giornalista, scrittore e fondatore di Vinous, tra le più importanti pubblicazioni enoiche al mondo, Antonio Galloni rappresenta una delle voci più autorevoli dell’enogiornalismo 🍷

Lunedì 12 giugno, nella cornice di Espressione Barbaresco, sarà un piacere averlo con noi in qualità di Voice of Barbaresco 2020 ed affidargli il racconto dell’ultima annata del Barbaresco DOCG 🍇
 
Attraverso la propria voce Galloni offrirà una lettura completa dell’annata 2020 del Barbaresco DOCG, declinata nel corso di una Masterclass esclusiva (solo su invito) e di una Lectio magistralis, dialogo a ruota libera con Alessandro Masnaghetti.

⚠️ Ultimi posti disponibili per la Lectio Magistralis (ore 15.30)

Getting ready to lead a Moon Mountain seminar at the historic Monte Rosso Vineyard. I have been visiting these vineyards for over a decade, before Moon Mountain was an AVA. This is a map we prepared for this tasting…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

It’s a gorgeous day in Napa Valley. Spending the next few days seeing vineyards for our St. Helena/Conn Valley & Howell Mountain maps, both of which are being updated for their second editions… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Terroirs of Napa Valley…what a fun seminar for one of our corporate private clients. I picked the wines based on what I seek most at this level: artisan values, wines that express the essence of site, vintage and variety. All the wines showed beautifully. Thank you to everyone at the Press Club for making this such a tremendous evening. 👏👏👏😍😍😍
Notes from our Selosse dinner a few months back now up on the home page. It was a lot of wine…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Epic hang with the boys…Il Professore, Map Man, The Kid and yours truly. Drinking not tasting…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

What a pleasure to share two Barbaresco seminars with Alessandro today. Our morning seminar focused on the 2020 Barbarescos while the afternoon session was a deep dive into the myriad nuances of geology and appellations. A great day so far…🤓🤓🤓
2022 Barolo en Primeur tasting today. These are the charity lots, single barrels that will be bottled with an artists’ label and sold this fall… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

When Il Professore speaks, I listen 😊. Beautiful bottles. My favorite Conterno was the 1978 Riserva, the first vintage made from Cascina Francia, even though it was not labeled as such. The 1989 was also a treat, it is from a vintage with no Monfortino (because of hail) and a total production of just one cask of Barolo. Krug 2006 was great, my third bottle of the week (don’t kill me), while the 2019 Rousseau Mazy (which I rarely taste from bottle) was sublime. Next…? Drinking, not tasting 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Fabulous dinner at Le Logge in Siena. Long overdue 😊😊😊. Many thanks to Mirco and team for taking such great care of me. Grazie ragazzi, e a presto! 😍😍😍🇮🇹😜😛

After unusually cool and rainy weather last week, summer has made an appearance. Great visit at Montevertine this morning. This is one the original Pergole Torte vineyards, first planted in the early 1980. Have been following these wines for a long time, lots of notes in our database 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

I can’t think of too many producers who offer to show a 12 vintage vertical of their entry-level wine where the youngest vintage is more than 20 years old, not cherry-picking just the best years, but rather showing the entire arc of their work over that time, great vintages, lesser vintages and everything in between. That’s what this was. San Giusto Chianti Classico 2001-1990. Remarkable wines from a remarkable family…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
I like tasting olive oil and learning about it just as much as wine. Don’t tell anyone…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Can’t wait to try this 😍😍😍
Definitely a bittersweet moment after Josh Raynolds’ passing earlier this year, but Nicolas Greinacher’s first report on Chateaneuf-du-Pape is outstanding. Bravo! On the Vinous homepage now…👏👏👏🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A first for me. Absolutely gorgeous and compelling Riesling 😊. Fabulous dinner at Le Bernardin, still one of my faves 😍😍😍
Kids…one day they are newborns, the next day they are visiting colleges 😂. We had a wonderful stay in Providence. I never fully appreciated what a gem of a city it is…🤓🤓🤓

location.city_name: Santa Rita Hills, Santa Barbara, California

social_posts.post_text: Great day in Santa Barbara. Started at 7am at Eleven Confessions, last appointment 6pm at Racines, where I took this pic. Black Sabbath on the radio 😊. Always a student…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

We are hiring an Operations Associate for our New York office in the Garment District. Help coordinate samples, tastings, events and more. This is a full-time position with paid time off, health insurance and more. You don’t have to be into wine, but if you are, you will taste the greatest wines in the world 😊. The ideal candidate is ambitious and excels with minimal supervision.

Please email jobs@vinous.com with your resume. Cheers!

Fabulous dinner last night at Bar Le Cote in Los Olivos. Not sure which was better, the superb food or talking guitars with Chef/Owner Brad Mathews all night. This is the Littleneck Clams & Chorizo. Epic and worth the trip. Delish! 😍😍😍🔥🔥🔥🎸🎸🎸

location.city_name: Santa Rita Hills, Santa Barbara, California

social_posts.post_text: I visited this vineyard for the first time more than a decade ago. It’s still one of my favorite sites in the world, especially for Chardonnay. This is Rita’s Crown, Sta. Rita Hills. Fabulous end of day…. 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A stunning view of the Sta. Rita Hills from the very top of Donnachadh, looking across to Sea Smoke and neighboring vineyards…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Sta. Rita Hills map research continues. Almost done. Well, it’s never done, but you know what I mean😊. This is Our Lady of Guadalupe, Dave Phinney’s new development on the western edge of the AVA. It’s a striking vineyard that also affords great views of neighboring estates. Doing my best to channel all the lessons @map_man_masna has taught me over the years 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Great father/son night out 😊. This is a fabulous film, maybe a bit slow to start, but then kicks into high gear. Certainly much better than the special effects laden, no real story movies that are so common today. The acting is amazing, such vivid portrayals. It’s a beautifully shot and presented story. I hear Barbie is next on my schedule 😂😂😂

Finally getting around to organizing my wine books, most of which were in storage following a pretty bad flood a few years ago. Better late than never 😊. This is one of my favorites. It was published in 2000. I lived in Milano at the time and used this book as my guide to the Langhe. I resolved to meet every producer featured and was fortunate to get pretty far through the list…quite a privilege, as so many of these growers are no longer with us. Maurizio Rosso does a great job in capturing the essence of Barolo…and what makes the wines and people there so special. The Mystique of Barolo made me fall even harder for these wines. Thank you, Maurizio. 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Here’s another book I have not seen for a few years. Aubert de Villaine gave this to me after an incredible set of tastings and meals with DRC wines I moderated in Toronto in 2015. His gracious inscription is in the second photo. The weekend remains one of the highlights of my career, with memories to last a lifetime. The 1971 La Tache from jeroboam is still one of the greatest wines I have ever had. Daniel Boulud and his team did an amazing job. Epic would be an understatement….😍😍😍
Festa del Barolo returns to NYC Jan 31 through Feb 3. We’ve got a killer program lined up. Can’t wait to share it with you… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Whenever I can I like to taste wines more than once. It’s a great day in our office for the team 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Time to check in on the 2010 Brunellos. We will be tasting through a number of the top wines on October 18 at our event at Locanda Verde in NY. Tickets are out today to our Premium subscribers. All the details on our events page, link in my bio…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A balmy day in Philadelphia. I think I have spent more time here in the last month than in my entire life…but it’s kinda fun…the brief illusion of youth 😂🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

The 2002 Monfortino. Can you believe that when this wine was released you could basically buy as much as you wanted? It’s a bit different these days 😊

This is one of the wines we will be serving at our Piedmont Icons dinner October 17 at Legacy Records in New York. As always, we strive to deliver a strong educational program along with reference point wines and vintages from leading estates. We will discuss the history of each property, farming practices and winemaking while tasting three wines each from Giuseppe Rinaldi, Giuseppe Mascarello, Giacomo Conterno, Bruno Giacosa and Roagna. Tickets available to our Premium subscribers now. All the details in my bio and the Events page at Vinous. Hope to see you there…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Mentors. I have been fortunate to have more than my fair share, people who have guided me during those difficult moments and times of change. So great to reconnect with old friends…😍😍😍

Taste top wines from the world’s leading estates, attend educational seminars, chat with our team of reviewers and taste library wines at our Gala Dinner. It’s all happening March 1 & 2, 2024 in New York. Vinous Icons… 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Morning kayak trip. Good wholesome family fun. We are going to sleep well tonight 😂😍

Sonoma report is out. The focus is mostly on 2021, but there are a bunch of other cool wines in there. This is one of my favorites….sparking Chardonnay from Chuy, one of the great sites on Moon Mountain and a vineyard I have long adored. (It’s now Kistler Midslope on our map, FYI) 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
There are few things I enjoy more than drinking Barolo with my parents. The 2018 Barolo from Oddero is gorgeous, it just needs a few hours of air if you want to drink it now 😍😍😍

Documenting the history of Napa Valley vineyards through our maps is a passion. Howell Mountain and St. Helena & Conn Valley, two of our most popular Napa Valley maps, are headed for their Second Editions. Available this fall 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
I don’t know anything about Loire wines, but I like this a lot. It’s the 2006. Last bottle from a six pack I bought on release. Thoroughly enjoyed them all. Time to drink 😍😍😍
Recent additions to the Vinous database. No summer slowdown here. It’s a pretty full publishing schedule for the next few weeks 😍😍😍

Fabulous dinner out with kiddos last night at Union Square Cafe. It’s great to see the kids’ growing interest in food beyond burgers and fries 😂. Corn agnolotti with truffles were terrific. They disappeared in an instant. Half chicken was delicious..crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Chocolate cake was…decadent. Washed it all down with the Jolie Laide Glou d’Etat. A fine evening all around 😍😍😍
Chianti Classico report is out…2021s and 2020s mostly….just under 450 reviews, vintage summaries, producer commentaries etc, you know the drill. These are some of the wines I loved 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

I visited Piedmont for the first time in 1997. It was a family vacation with my parents and sister. We rented a very humble agriturismo and explored a different town each day. I already knew the wines a bit, but seeing the places where they were made changed everything. Since then I have felt an incredible attraction to this place, as if the land physically pulls me to it. So great to be back 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Belated birthday dinner. Worth the wait 😂. All the bottles were great, but the skies opened and the angels sang for the 1955 Mascarello and 1998 Soldera. Boys night 😊. None of these are my birth year, in case you are wondering 😂😂😂
In my opinion, the most under the radar estate in Piedmont today 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

To my fellow diners who sent this over for us to taste….thank you!! The 1995 Santo Stefano is a pretty, smaller scaled Barbaresco that has aged impeccably. I loved it 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍. Wonderful dinner at Centro Storico. Delicious and fast…what I always want 😊😊😊

Fabulous birthday dinner at Il Centro. To my dear friend who brought the Barolos…Grazie 😊! 

The 2020 Jobard Genevrieres is gorgeous, a bit reduced (but not too much) and a pleasure to drink. I did what I usually do, which is just have a bit to start, and then have a nice glass at the end of the meal with cheese. The 1970 Pira Barolo is a cult wine, made from a blend of vineyards, with 100% whole bunches. It always needs a ton of air. The 1999 Monfortino is more like a drug than a wine. It has Giovanni Conterno’s style written all over it 😊. 

For food…Elide Mollo and her team made many of my favorites…marinated red pepper, carne cruda (family style) and also a killer insalata russa, which is not usually on the menu, but is elevated to the realm of the extraordinary here. Ravioli with seirass…delectable. And then, my #1 Piedmont Hack…I always order salad and/or veggies. They are rarely on the menu, but any good place will more than accomodate, and greens will extend your ability to enjoy the food here for a long time 😊. Thanks to the Cordero family and their staff for another great birthday dinner 😍😍😍
Back in Chianti Classico to check out vineyards. Such a gorgeous time of year. This is part of Antinori’s sprawling Tignanello property…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Join me for what is sure to be an incredible tasting of West Sonoma Coast wines on October 25th in NY. Over the years I have been fortunate to have a front row seat as this rugged stretch of land went from a loose collection of vineyards to a formal AVA. The formidable Alessandro Masnaghetti and our team worked to create the official map of the AVA, the first in a series that includes maps of the nested Fort Ross-Seaview AVA, other districts and single properties. On October 25 I will share our latest work, none of which has been shown to the public before. And of course attendees will have a chance to taste a number of exceptional wines and chat with winemakers. It’s going to be an amazing day. Link to sign up is in my bio. 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Spent the day visiting vineyards in Lamole, one of the most intriguing districts in Chianti Classico today. Had this over a simple, delicious lunch at Ristoro di Lamole 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
High density, head-trained Sangiovese in Le Boncie’s Le Trame vineyard. Harvest starts in the morning. Andiamo! 🇮🇹😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Harvest is well under way at Rodano. Such an exciting time of year… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Silvio Messana makes some of the most compelling wines in Chianti Classico at Montesecondo. I had no idea we overlapped at Berklee and both studied privately with jazz great Jerry Bergonzi. Later, we worked at restaurants in Boston’s Beacon Hill that were practically next to each other. That is just…crazy. Here Messana talks about his love for John Coltrane, Sonny Rollins and Keith Jarrett. A nice break from the usual yada yada yada of soils, clones, rootstocks etc…🇮🇹😍🤓

Santa Barbara report is out. Nearly 900 reviews, regional updates, producer commentaries, vintage overviews etc. IMO, Santa Barbara is one of the last, maybe THE last, world class region the global wine trade has not latched on to… 🤓🤓🤓
This week we also published reviews on the full range of 2021s from Rhys. Busy week…just the way we like it 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
The Saturday vibe here on this cold fall morning. Copious amounts of espresso. Black. Several hours of practice ahead. Perfect… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Fall is in the air, and that has me thinking about Nebbiolo today. We’ve got a great event coming up on October 17 at Legacy Records in NYC. So great to be back in Napa Valley. I loved the 2013 when it was first released and I love it today just as much, maybe a little more 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
First 2023s of this trip. At Opus One, where 45% of the crop is in. Many others are just getting started. What a gorgeous fall day. Like it used to be 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A chat with Molly Chappellet was the highlight of this visit. She is still sharp as a tack. Not one grape has been picked here yet and won’t be anytime soon. Such an interesting vintage 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

A wonderful afternoon for a visit with the Togni family. Philip Togni in splendid form as he approaches his 70th harvest and 97th birthday. Harvest scheduled to start on Monday. As for the 2013, it is as epic as ever 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Loved this when it was young, love it today. Not all wines made in the more opulent style of Napa Valley have aged well, the 2013 Sloan most certainly has. Superb… 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Today’s lineup at Realm. A fascinating contrast of eras and styles…2021s and 2013s…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Very quiet today at Wheeler Farms. Not much going on at the moment. There is still a lot of Cabernet waiting to be picked. Many places will start this week, some don’t intend to start until later in the month. There are some exceptions among early pickers, some sites on the valley floor and larger wineries that have to pick for practical reasons. At this stage, it looks like everything will be condensed into a short period of time, which will create its own set of challenges. There was some rain on Saturday but for now looking like pretty ideal conditions. Fingers crossed. It’s an interesting time in the valley, with some weakness on the macro front and what looks to be an average to slightly higher than average crop. Never a dull moment 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
It’s the 2013. Loved it when it was young, love it today 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

A terrific way to end this spectacular fall day. The 2013 Hillside Select is still young, but much more finessed than it was as a young wine. First day of harvest at Shafer. Exactly one month later than last year. Amazing. In the background is a map we did of all the clones planted in the various blocks here. Such a fascinating estate because of all that complexity 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Good morning from Dominus. Harvest starts tomorrow. Looks like a gorgeous crop…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

A bonus feature for Vinous readers today. Check out our homepage for an excerpt from Alessandro Masnaghetti’s new Barolo book, along with details on how you can pick up your copy. It’s essential reading for anyone who loves Barolo or wants to learn more about the great wines of Piedmont. I have had the privilege or working with Alessandro for close to a decade now on our California project. He is one of those annoyingly brilliant people who is in their own category, someone who always inspires me to be better. This book is absolutely phenomenal. It’s a limited print run, so don’t miss it. Bravo Alessandro 💯👏👏👏
A spectacular wine that has aged beautifully through its first decade. Still very young with plenty of life ahead of it… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
The 2013 from Cornell, in splendid shape. This is the first important vintage for the estate, and a huge step up from the wines that preceded it. Super impressive 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

I have been fortunate to taste The Vineyardist from the very first vintage and to follow all the developments here over the years. The 2013 was fabulous as a young wine and is every bit as compelling today 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Detert East Block Cabernet Franc. There are several new buyers for Detert fruit this year. It will be interesting to see what they do… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Weekend vibe around here…🤓🤓🤓
49ers and Raveneau…a fine Sunday so far…It’s the 2017 Butteaux, still very youthful 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Monday Night Football wines…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓. Fascinating side by side contrast
One of my favorites and a regular purchase since I started tasting them 15-16 years ago. La Boloree is probably my favorite in the range 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Tonight we drink Barolo. Five reference point estates, benchmark wines and vintages. Should be fun and educational 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

This is how it turned out last night. Stellar tasting and dinner at Legacy Records. Thanks to the team at Legacy for taking care of all of the details with the utmost skill. 

All the wines were gorgeous, and they all told a story, which is why I chose the wines and vintages. My main takeaway was how great all the 2004s are. It’s a very special vintage for me. The first complete vintage I tasted at The Wine Advocate. I immediately loved the wines for their freshness and energy. One evening, after a long day of tastings, I pulled off the road, called Bob Parker and told him 2004 was a great vintage. I asked him to please set aside a number of pages in the hard copy edition of the next issue. He did. When I got home that article wrote itself. I was so inspired by the wines. At the time, not everyone was convinced. Some people thought the wines were too light, that yields were too high. Now, 20 years later, the best 2004s are vibrant, fresh and spectacularly beautiful. What a night 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

2010 Brunello di Montalcino was the focus of last night’s stellar dinner at Locanda Verde. What a fun night. Most of the wines showed beautifully. I especially loved the Salvioni and Stella di Campalto. If you have the 2010s, it’s time to start drinking them 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

It’s been a busy few weeks with a ton of events. This masterclass on Abruzzo was so much fun. I really enjoyed choosing the wines for this seminar and presenting them. I haven’t reviewed current releases personally for some years. I found that allowed me to approach the region and its wines with a combination of excitement over recent developments and experience from the past. I hope everyone who attended enjoyed it. Special thanks to the team at the Fifth Avenue Hotel who did a great job despite not being fully open yet…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Barolo 2023 En Primeur Charity Auction takes place this coming Friday at 12pm New York time, streamed live with connections from Grinzane Cavour and London. Single barrels of 2022 Barolo plus village lots featuring wines from many of the regions’s top producers. Christie’s is the official auctioneer. My report on the 2022 single barrel wines is on the Vinous home page. Interested bidders can still sign up for the live auction at Christie’s HQ in New York by emailing us. There are just a few spots left. As always I will bring a few great bottles for my table 🚀🚀🚀😍😍😍
Barbaresco 2020 & 2021 reviews are out. Vintage profiles, producer commentaries and reviews. On our home page now. Cigliuti is among my favorites in 2020. Fabulous wines…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

For me, all of the world’s great wines have one thing in common: they are expressions of place. The first time I visited the West Sonoma Coast, I knew immediately I had found wines that met that criteria. It was the early 2010s. There was no West Sonoma Coast AVA, the petition had not even been filed. But I saw some of the early supporting documents. I wanted to do a map, like all our maps, inspired by the Pitiot maps of Burgundy and the Masnaghetti maps of Piedmont. Little did I know that a few years later we would begin collaborating with Alessandro on a series of California maps. Last night I was delighted to present our work so far 1) West Sonoma Coast AVA map (available digitally 2) Fort Ross-Seaview AVA (in draft form) and maps of numerous single properties. Together, these maps allow curious wine lovers to learn more about the West Sonoma Coast than ever before. It was great to see so many Vinous subscribers and taste so many beautiful wines in less formal conditions than I am used to 😊. Next…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

So excited to be in Toronto, one of my favorite cities, for a very special vertical of D’Angerville Clos des Ducs (all from magnum) to benefit the UHN Foundation, which raises funds for a number of Toronto hospitals. Just tasted through all the wines. Someone had to do it 😊. Allez…! 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Barolo 2023 En Primeur Charity Auction is in the books. All lots sold at a fabulous event held at Christie’s HQ. Shrewd buyers came away with some terrific wines. All proceeds go to the Oenological School of Alba, plus selected local and international charities. Have been involved with this project since the beginnng. Great to see it grow. Many thanks to our generous donors 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

I like the Classics. Always have. Things that never go out of style. Could be wine, food, music, art, fashion etc. At a time when so many are obsessed with the latest, greatest, newest thing and when prices for some wines have reached the stratosphere, some stand out for their timeless classicism. D’Angerville’s Clos des Ducs is one of them. I was delighted to be a part of this vertical, vintages 2017-1993, with Guillaume d’Angerville. The dinner was organized by Halpern Enterprises to benefit the UHN Foundation, which supports a number of hospitals in Toronto. I would like to thank collector Frank Davis, who donated most of these wines, all in magnum, Sash Simpson and his team for a fabulous meal, everyone who worked behind the scenes to make this event come off without a hitch, and of course all of our generous benefactors for their support. It’s always a pleasure to spend time with this impressive group of doctors and wine lovers, always for a great cause. See you next time…👏👏👏😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Just published another set of Barolo reviews, on the Vinous homepage now. Manzone remains one of the undiscovered gems. Wines have been especially brilliant of late 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Early morning fog has lifted…it’s a great time to start tasting…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍. First trip here was in 1997…😂

Catching up on some photos from a fabulous dinner on Friday night at The Polo Bar. It was great to see old friends and make new friends too. As always the burger is worth a visit. It was especially delicious with our red Burgundies. Too many superb wines to pick favorites, although the 2017 Leflaive Chevalier, 1990 Rouget  and 1990 Truchot were especially memorable 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Tasting from barrel is a great opportunity to learn what future vintages hold in store. Bartolo Mascarello was the first grower I met in Barolo, so this is always a special visit. The 1982 Barolo was a life changing wine for me 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Last tasting of the day. Always so educational…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Burlotto….last tasting of the day. It’s the entire range that’s terrific here…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Piedmont has a ton of great restaurants. I am always so happy to be here. Thank you Piero and Ugo Alciati & team for a great night! The Mascarello is 1970 and the Monfortino 1971…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Morning visit at Cappellano. I showed up on the wrong day, but was still able taste 😊. It’s a miracle that does not happen more often. This is the 2023 Barolo Rupestris undergoing submerged cap maceration prior to malo. Drought and mildew wiped out 60% of production, so the 2023s will be even more impossible to find than normal. Just one vat (as opposed to two) of the Rupestris and a few hundred bottles of the Pie Franco…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Fabulous dinner at Il Centro. The Cordero family embodies the essence of old school Piedmontese hospitality, so it is always great to spend time here. All the dishes were sublime. For the wines, the 1970 Monfortino is an utterly magical Barolo. Only a magnum is better 😊. We will be back soon…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Fun early dinner at Centro Storico. My favorite was the Gaja Barbaresco. The 1950s and 1960s wines there in particular are so special. The 1979 Mascarello Rionda is a one and done deal. Giacosa wavered on the fruit that year and Mascarello scooped it up. I have never had the 1984 Mascarello Vignasette, never even heard of this vineyard if it is one. Interesting wine, but it has not aged as well as Van Halen’s ‘Jump’ which was playing as it was served 😊. I always eat the same thing here…plate of vegetables and pasta 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
First vintage, has aged incredibly gracefully, even with a touch of cork taint. A treat to taste this today 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Fun dinner tonight at one of my homes away from home. The two 1978 Giacosa Red Labels were a treat to drinki side by side. I preferred the Rionda because of its perfume and sensual fruit. But the most surprising wine of the night was the 1965 Mascarello Barolo. I don’t think I have ever had a wine from this vintage. The Mascarello showed some clear signs of rot in its flavor profile, but was also exceptionally finessed and silky on the palate, plus it has aged beautifully. Quite a revelation… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Fun to taste the 2022s at DRC today with @nealmartin123 and a few colleagues. I did not break a glass this time, so that’s progress 😊. The last few years I have especially been taken by the GE, which looks to be very fine again in 2022. Tasting La Tache from barrels of two different coopers was enlightening. As always, I am so grateful my mom, who made me take four years of French in high school…😂🤓😍
One of my favorite tastings in Burgundy. The 2022s with Louis-Michel Liger-Belair. Every wine has so much to explore. I love the educational part of tastings like this the most….🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Alain Burguet was one of the first Burgundian vignerons I met, well before I was writing about wine. The domaine, today under the direction of son Jean-Luc Burguet, remains one of my favorite small producers in Burgundy. Great visit this morning 🤓🤓🤓

One of the most fabled entrances in Burgundy. I have been fortunate to taste here many times over the years, but my favorite memory will always be carrying my son, then less than a year old, down these steps in a baby stroller in 2007. You can do that in Italy, but I would not recommend it in France 😂😂😂

When I was a kid, my dad told me about a wine called Gattinara. He told me it was one of the great noble wines of Italy and was once more renowned than Barolo and Barbaresco. I listened. He might say that was one of the rare times I listened 😂. Anyway, that was the beginning of my fascination with Gattinara and the wines of Alto Piemonte. This was a fabulous dinner and great exploration of some older wines. The bottles were a bit variable in some cases but still super educational 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Great to be back in New York, even if for just a few days. Fabulous dinner at The Polo Bar…, 2019 Occidental Cuvée Catherine and the burger. About as good as it gets in my book…😋😋😋😍😍😍
Thats 5lbs of jumbos, from ocean to table 😋😋😋
Working from home…

Another wonderful recent NYC meal. I love the classics. Gramercy Tavern is certainly that, and yet also feels very contemporary. Last minute walk in, no reservation, no problem. Great food, wine and hospitality. A fabulous way to spend an afternoon 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Fun to revisit my collection of records at my parents’ house, especially now that vinyl is back in fashion 😂. I bought all of these in high school, and all were incredibly influential. There are many more. When I look back I realize how fortunate I was to be exposed to these artists at a young age…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Vinous Maps…one day only. Buy one, get one free. Check out the link in my bio for more information. It’s been a very busy year. We published for maps: Coombsville, Sta. Rita Hills and newly updated Second Editions of Howell Mountain and St. Helena & Conn Valley. These are the most comprehensive maps of American AVAs out there. Santa Lucia Highlands report is out. Tough to write this one following Josh Raynolds’ passing earlier this year. The SLH is a region I have long had a soft spot for as my parents sold a lot of the first vintages of Mer Soleil back in the 1990s…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Grabbed this for dinner tonight. Just stellar…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

I have to say, I am complete in awe of the books published by my colleagues and peers this year. Wow. It’s a great time to stock your bookshelf with the latest books and to think about gifts too. I have profiled five new books in our Holiday Gift Guide, on the Vinous home page now. I don’t claim to be totally objective about the books written by our writers, but I have watched some of these go from an early concept to finished book, a huge achievement in and of it itself. Not pictured is Rebecca Gibb MW’s Vintage Crime…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

When I was a kid, my dad told me there were two great wines in the world: Champagne and Barolo. Not a bad way to start 😂. Champagne has been one of my focuses for more than 15 years. It’s such an exciting region, but also ao dynamic that it’s hard to keep up. This year I asked my esteemed colleague Anne Krebiehl MW to contribute to our Champagne coverage. We just posted her notes, 250+, and could be more delighted. This shared report is our most comprehensive Champagne coverage yet, but we are just getting started. Allez… 🥂🥂🥂
2016 Canon…one of the wines that will be featured at Vinous Icons, March 1 and 2 in NYC. See you there… 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

An article I have wanted to publish for a while. This was an amazing tasting at Roederer. Chef de Caves Jean-Baptiste Lecaillon presented every vintage of Cristal he has made and released since becoming Chef de Caves in 1999. Last wine was a magnum of late disgorged 1993 that almost was the first Vinotheque. On our home page now…🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
A beautiful morning in Paris. It’s been too long…😍😍😍

Insipring. A total sensory experience. Christian Dior revolutionized the fashion industry, inspired so many designers who followed him and built an enduring, iconic, classic brand during his very short life. La Galerie Dior is well worth a visit…😍😍😍
Spectacular dinner at Yannick Alleno’s PavYllon. Fabulous food, service and overall hospitality. A great experience all around 😍😍😍
Thank you Arnaud Donckele and your team for an unforgettable night. More than just a meal, dinner at Plenitude is a total gustatory and sensory experience. Superb…😍😍😍
Paris by night. Is there a more spectacular city??? 😍😍😍

In the spring of 2010 I met up with Bob Parker in New York. Bob had just come back from Bordeaux. He told me all about the 2009s, how it was the greatest vintage he had ever tasted. Every time I drink a 2009 Bordeaux I think about Bob and that conversation. The 2009 Pauillac from Chateau Latour is fabulous. And young. It’s more extracted and oakier than the wines of today, and yet it is aging exceptionally well. I rarely eat foie gras, but wow, was this great. And the pairing was sublime…😍😍😍

Late afternoon/early evening is my favorite time to taste. Almost everyone has gone home, wineries are eerily quiet and there are no distractions. In spring 2017, I visited Haut-Batailley, just after the Cazes family purchased it. Today I had a chance to taste all the wines they have made since then. Building that sort of historical context is something I truly love… 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Finally some sun in Bordeaux 😊. Les Carmes Haut-Brion. One of Bordeaux’s most cutting edge properties. Check out the wines and chat with Estate Director Guillaume Pouthier at Vinous Icons, March 1 and 2 in NYC. 2018s and 2020s at our walk around tasting, older vintages at a special dinner curated by @nealmartin123 on Feb 29 @legacyrecordsrestaurant
Buongiorno! 😍🤓🇮🇹

One of my dreams for Vinous has long been that we would be an incubator for talent, a place where we could discover, nurture and develop the next generation of wine writers. With that in mind, a few years ago, we launched the Vinous Young Wine Writers Fellowship, which is funded by Vinous and is intended to give aspiring young wine writers an opportunity to travel and pursue their aspirations. Earlier this year, we renamed the fellowship in honor of our late colleague Josh Raynolds. Josh loved wine, life and encouraging young professionals, so it seems apt that the fellowship will honor his memory going forward.

We received many high-quality applications this year. Making a final decision was very difficult. In the end, the editorial board’s choice was unanimous. I am thrilled to announce that Sedale McCall is the recipient of the 2023 Vinous Josh Raynolds Young Wine Writers Fellowship. Sedale’s writing impressed us with his enthusiasm to amplify unique regions and inform consumers about what wine has to offer.

I would also like to congratulate our two runners-up, Charlotte Adams Alsaadi and Liam Hosey, both of whom submitted compelling applications and have very bright futures. Lastly, I would like to thank everyone who took the time to apply for the 2023 Vinous Josh Raynolds Young Wine Writers Fellowship.

Today, we raise a glass to congratulate Sedale McCall. We can’t wait to share his writing with you. 🥂🎉👏👏👏
Sunday night wine. Nice to be home 😍😍😍
What a week…Napa Valley report is out, 2021s and 2022s. Vintage reports, producer commentaries and reviews. Always a pleasure to be there 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

It’s been quite the year. My end of year wrap up is on the home page now. Check it out to see the highlights and which wines, wineries and winemakers did exceptionally well. This photo is from our 2 day Soldera tasting. Every vintage back to the inaugural 1977 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Making dinner and drinking this. A fine cold weather Piedmontese red 😍😍😍
Wonderful last night. Perfect for the occasion 😍😍😍

Hazelnut chocolate cake. A super traditional recipe. Don’t make it often, but it is really good 😍😍😍. Trick is to use real Piedmontese hazelnuts, that’s 80% of it…
