Spoiling my parents with their favorite wines. The 2002 Dom Perignon remains epic. I remember tasting it with longtime Chef de Caves Richard Geoffroy before it was released. Elevated ripeness in the Chardonnays yielded a decidedly exotic DP, one I have always loved. The 2001 Conterno Cascina Francia. What a wine. In perfect shape. By 2001, generational transition was under way. It was the first year the Barbera went back to longer aging in wood. Dolcetto and Freisa had come out. But the 2001 Cascina Francia is Giovanni Conterno’s wine. The acid, tannin and structural profiles are very clearly those of another era. Super classic to the core. We loved it 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
And…we are back. First article of 2024 is an in depth look at one of my favorite Champagnes, the Rosé de Saignée Les Maillons from Ulysse Collin. On the home page now…😍😍😍

Sensing my growing interest in wine, my parents gave me books to read when I was in high school. I wanted to know what every word on a label meant. When we went out for dinner, they would let me order their wine, so I could learn how to do that. I was reading about Burgundy one day and was intrigued by wines from a village named ‘Meursault.’ So, that’s what I ordered for them. My grandfather, who knew quite a bit about French wine, was aghast 🤣. I wonder what I ordered…In any event, I have always loved these wines, and the wines made by the Lafon family. The 2019 Clos de la Barre with mom and dad last night was great. Young, but so delicious 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍

Barolo 2020 report is out now. All you need to know. In depth vintage commentary, dozens of producer commentaries and nearly 400 reviews…2020 Barolo, late release 2019 and the best Dolcettos, Barberas and other affordable wines I think are an essential part of the region’s fabric. Plus the perspective I have gained in 27 years of visiting the region, every year, the good, the not so good and the great. On our home page now 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
Littorai 2022s and 2021s. A great way to start the day. Also a big improvement over last year, when it rained every single day I was in Sonoma 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤣

So great to catch up with an old friend last night. We had a fabulous time. And dinner was magnificent. The duck…sublime 😋😋😋. For the wines, I love Sta. Rita Hills Chardonnay. The 2020 Mae from Tyler was superb. The Rinaldi Barolo is a very rare wine, the pure Brunate. Vintage 2009, my first time trying it. I am generally not the biggest fan of this vintage, but what a wine. Bright red and vibrant, the 2009 is so young. When asked, I often suggest readers focus on producer over vintage. This is why…😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓
A fine conclusion to the day. Ultramarine 2018 Rose Hirsch Vineyard…mindbending. Have loved these wines since I started tasting them years ago. 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Taste some of the world’s most exciting wines, chat with winemakers and meet our team of reviewers. It’s all happening at Vinous Icons, Feb 29-Mar 2 in NYC. See you there! 😍😍😍🤓🤓🤓

Great to taste the rest of the bottled 2021s at DuMOL today (I tasted the others last year). Come meet Owner/Winemaker Andy Smith at Vinous Icons, Feb 29 to Mar 2 in NYC. I love Sonoma Cabernet Sauvignon, always have. Kenwood’s 2001 Artist Series was in great shape last night. What a wine! Still fresh and vibrant, it has plenty of life ahead. And it’s also in better shape than many 2001 Cabernets from the other side of the Mayacamas Mountains. Fabulous dinner at Glen Ellen Star, one of my favorites… 😋😋😋🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
We had a fabulous dinner at The Matheson last night. Great space, food and vibe. Wine was 2021 Hirsch Bohan Dillon, forgot to take a pic 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
Perfect meal at the end of a week of tastings? A burger and good Champagne is way up there for me. We had a great time at Mustards last night 😍😍😍😋😋😋

We had a superb dinner at Angler last night. Thanks to the staff for making it so great. Everything was delicious. Very happy to find the Clerget Chevalieres on the list. It’s one of my favorite not crazy white Burgundies 😋😋😋😍😍😍

January means Sonoma. First reviews of 2022s and some 2021s out today. Vintage report and more reviews folllow on Thursday. The Dolinsek is one of my favorite wines in the Bedrock range this year. I drove past that ranch many times last week. As much as I admire the Bedorck wines, I am equally impressed with their decision to move to lower weight bottles. It’s one thing to talk about sustainability, but something entirely different to act on it. The new bottles lower the weight of a single case of wine by 9 lbs. That’s an astonishing number, especially when multiplied across thousands of cases, and, ideally, many thousands of wineries that might follow suit. 👏👏👏🤓🤓🤓

Second set of Sonoma reviews and my vintage write up are on our home page now. More than publishing just brief reviews and scores, our team strives to provide real insight. That’s one of the reasons every producer entry in this report includes commentary on their harvest, winemaking, evolution or other things I found of interest while tasting with the winemakers 🤓🤓🤓😍😍😍
